Item2.SourceOrg: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/

Item2.Name: Barro-Lee: Average years of tertiary schooling, age 60-64, female
Item2.SourceNote: Average years of tertiary schooling, 60-64, female is the average years of tertiary education completed among females age 60-64.
Item2.SourceOrg: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/

Item2.Name: Barro-Lee: Average years of tertiary schooling, age 65-69, total
Item2.SourceNote: Average years of tertiary schooling, 65-69, total is the average years of tertiary education completed among people age 65-69.
Item2.SourceOrg: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/

Item2.Name: Barro-Lee: Average years of tertiary schooling, age 65-69, female
Item2.SourceNote: Average years of tertiary schooling, 65-69, female is the average years of tertiary education completed among females age 65-69.
Item2.SourceOrg: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/

Item2.Name: Barro-Lee: Average years of tertiary schooling, age 70-74, total
Item2.SourceNote: Average years of tertiary schooling, 70-74, total is the average years of tertiary education completed among people age 70-74.
Item2.SourceOrg: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/

Item2.Name: Barro-Lee: Average years of tertiary schooling, age 70-74, female
Item2.SourceNote: Average years of tertiary schooling, 70-74, female is the average years of tertiary education completed among females age 70-74.
Item2.SourceOrg: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/

Item2.Name: Barro-Lee: Average years of tertiary schooling, age 75+, total
Item2.SourceNote: Average years of tertiary schooling, 75+, total is the average years of tertiary education completed among people over age 75.
Item2.SourceOrg: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/

Item2.Name: Barro-Lee: Average years of tertiary schooling, age 75+, female
Item2.SourceNote: Average years of tertiary schooling, 75+, female is the average years of tertiary education completed among females over age 75.
Item2.SourceOrg: Robert J. Barro and Jong-Wha Lee: http://www.barrolee.com/

Item2.Name: Barley, $/mt, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Barley (Canada), feed, Western No. 1, Winnipeg Commodity Exchange, spot, wholesale farmers' price
Item2.SourceOrg: Bloomberg; World Bank.

Item2.Name: Meat, beef, cents/kg, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Meat, beef (Australia/New Zealand), chucks and cow forequarters, frozen boneless, 85% chemical lean, c.i.f. U.S. port (East Coast), ex-dock, beginning November 2002; previously cow forequarters
Item2.SourceOrg: Meat & Livestock Australia, Meat and Livestock Weekly; The National Provisioner; US Department of Agriculture;  World Bank.

Item2.Name: Trade in services (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Trade in services is the sum of service exports and imports divided by the value of GDP, all in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

Item2.Name: Agricultural tractors, exports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Agricultural machinery refers to the number of wheel and crawler tractors (excluding garden tractors) in use in agriculture at the end of the calendar year specified or during the first quarter of the following year.  Data are in US$.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Agricultural tractors, exports
Item2.SourceNote: Agricultural machinery refers to the number of wheel and crawler tractors (excluding garden tractors) in use in agriculture at the end of the calendar year specified or during the first quarter of the following year.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Cereal exports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Cereals include wheat, rice, maize, barley, oats, rye, millet, sorghum, buckwheat, and mixed grains. Production data on cereals relate to crops harvested for dry grain only. Cereal crops harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Cereal exports quantity (FAO, tonnes)
Item2.SourceNote: Cereals include wheat, rice, maize, barley, oats, rye, millet, sorghum, buckwheat, and mixed grains. Production data on cereals relate to crops harvested for dry grain only. Cereal crops harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Forest products imports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Forest products imports.  Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Hazardous pesticides imports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Pesticides refer to insecticides, fungicides, herbicides, disinfectants and any substance or mixture of substances intended for preventing, destroying or controlling any pest, including vectors of human or animal disease, unwanted species of plants or animals causing harm during or otherwise interfering with the production, processing, storage, transport or marketing of food, agricultural commodities, wood and wood products or animal feedstuffs, or substances which may be administered to animals for the control of insects, arachnids or other pests in or on their bodies.  The term includes substances intended for use as a plant growth regulator, defoliant, desiccant or agent for thinning fruit or preventing the premature fall of fruit, and substances applied to crops either before or after harvest to protect the commodity from deterioration during storage and transport.  Pesticide trade is the value of trade covering insecticides, fungicides, herbicides, disinfectants and others, as described by the Harmonised Coding System (HS) code 3808.  Differences between figures given for total exports and total imports at the world level may be due to several factors, e.g. the time lag between the dispatch of goods from exporting country and their arrival in the importing country; the use of different classification of the same product by different countries; or the fact that some countries supply data on general trade while others give data on special trade.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Pesticides imports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Pesticides refer to insecticides, fungicides, herbicides, disinfectants and any substance or mixture of substances intended for preventing, destroying or controlling any pest, including vectors of human or animal disease, unwanted species of plants or animals causing harm during or otherwise interfering with the production, processing, storage, transport or marketing of food, agricultural commodities, wood and wood products or animal feedstuffs, or substances which may be administered to animals for the control of insects, arachnids or other pests in or on their bodies. The term includes substances intended for use as a plant growth regulator, defoliant, desiccant or agent for thinning fruit or preventing the premature fall of fruit, and substances applied to crops either before or after harvest to protect the commodity from deterioration during storage and transport.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Food imports excluding fish (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Food imports excludes fish.  Data are expressed in current U.S. dollar at cost-insurance-freight (cif) prices. Excludes fish.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Total agricultural imports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Total agricultural imports are expressed in terms of value.  They cover all movements into the country of the commodity in question during the reference period. They include commercial trade, food aid granted on specific terms, donated quantities and estimates of unrecorded trade.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Communications, computer, etc. (% of service imports, BoP)
Item2.SourceNote: Communications, computer, information, and other services cover international telecommunications; computer data; news-related service transactions between residents and nonresidents; construction services; royalties and license fees; miscellaneous business, professional, and technical services; personal, cultural, and recreational services; manufacturing services on physical inputs owned by others; and maintenance and repair services and government services not included elsewhere.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Primary income payments (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Primary income payments refer to employee compensation paid to nonresident workers and investment income (payments on direct investment, portfolio investment, other investments). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Other income payments (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Other income payments.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: Imports of goods and services (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Imports of goods and services comprise all transactions between residents of a country and the rest of the world involving a change of ownership from nonresidents to residents of general merchandise, nonmonetary gold, and services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Insurance and financial services (% of service imports, BoP)
Item2.SourceNote: Insurance and financial services cover various types of insurance provided to nonresidents by resident insurance enterprises and vice versa, and financial intermediary and auxiliary services (except those of insurance enterprises and pension funds) exchanged between residents and nonresidents.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Goods imports (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Goods imports refer to all movable goods (including nonmonetary gold) involved in a change of ownership from nonresidents to residents. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Service imports (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Services refer to economic output of intangible commodities that may be produced, transferred, and consumed at the same time. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Charges for the use of intellectual property, payments (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Charges for the use of intellectual property are payments and receipts between residents and nonresidents for the authorized use of proprietary rights (such as patents, trademarks, copyrights, industrial processes and designs including trade secrets, and franchises) and for the use, through licensing agreements, of produced originals or prototypes (such as copyrights on books and manuscripts, computer software, cinematographic works, and sound recordings) and related rights (such as for live performances and television, cable, or satellite broadcast). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Imports of  total services (Debit, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Imports of total services is calculated as the difference between imports of goods and services and merchandise imports.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: Imports of goods, services and primary income (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Imports of goods, services and primary income is the sum of goods imports, service imports and primary income payments. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Transport services (% of service imports, BoP)
Item2.SourceNote: Transport covers all transport services (sea, air, land, internal waterway, pipeline, space and electricity transmission) performed by residents of one economy for those of another and involving the carriage of passengers, the movement of goods (freight), rental of carriers with crew, and related support and auxiliary services. Also included are postal and courier services. Excluded are freight insurance (included in insurance services); goods procured in ports by nonresident carriers (included in goods); maintenance and repairs on transport equipment (included in maintenance and repair services n.i.e.); and repairs of railway facilities, harbors, and airfield facilities (included in construction).
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Travel services (% of service imports, BoP)
Item2.SourceNote: Travel covers goods and services acquired from an economy by travelers for their own use during visits of less than one year in that economy for either business or personal purposes. Travel includes local transport (i.e., transport within the economy being visited and provided by a resident of that economy), but excludes international transport (which is included in passenger transport. Travel also excludes goods for resale, which are included in general merchandise.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Foreign direct investment, net outflows by reporting economy (IMF-BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Foreign direct investment are the net inflows of investment to acquire a lasting management interest (10 percent or more of voting stock) in an enterprise operating in an economy other than that of the investor. It is the sum of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, other long-term capital, and short-term capital as shown in the balance of payments. This series shows net outflows of investment from the reporting economy to the rest of the world. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Current transfers, payments (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Current transfers comprise transfers of income between residents of the reporting country and the rest of the world that carry no provisions for repayment. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Migrant remittance outflows (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Migrants’ remittances are defined as the sum of worker’s remittances,
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff estimates based on the International Monetary Fund's Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook 2008.

Item2.Name: Official current transfers, payments (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Current transfers are recorded in the balance of payments whenever an economy provides or receives goods, services, income, or financial items without a quid pro quo. All transfers not considered to be capital are current. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Secondary income, other sectors, payments (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Secondary income refers to transfers recorded in the balance of payments whenever an economy provides or receives goods, services, income, or financial items without a quid pro quo. All transfers not considered to be capital are current. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Workers' remittances, payments (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Workers' remittances are current transfers by migrants who are employed or intend to remain employed for more than a year in another economy in which they are considered residents. Some developing countries classify workers' remittances as a factor income receipt (and thus as a component of GNI). The World Bank adheres to international guidelines in defining GNI, and its classification of workers' remittances may therefore differ from national practices. This item shows payments by the reporting country. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Personal remittances, paid (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Personal remittances comprise personal transfers and compensation of employees. Personal transfers consist of all current transfers in cash or in kind made or received by resident households to or from nonresident households. Personal transfers thus include all current transfers between resident and nonresident individuals. Compensation of employees refers to the income of border, seasonal, and other short-term workers who are employed in an economy where they are not resident and of residents employed by nonresident entities. Data are the sum of two items defined in the sixth edition of the IMF's Balance of Payments Manual: personal transfers and compensation of employees. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff estimates based on IMF balance of payments data.

Item2.Name: Current account balance (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Current account balance is the sum of net exports of goods and services, net primary income, and net secondary income. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Current account balance (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Current account balance is the sum of net exports of goods and services, net primary income, and net secondary income.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

Item2.Name: Current account balance (% of GNP)
Item2.SourceNote: Current account balance is the sum of net exports of goods, services, net income, and net current transfers. Data are in current U.S. dollars.  Data are divided by GNP at market prices in U.S. dollars to facilitate comparison across economies.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Current account balance excluding net official capital grants (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Current account balance is the sum of net exports of goods, services, net income, and net current transfers.  This is divided by GDP at market prices, with both series expressed in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: Debt service not paid (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Debt service not paid (BoP, current US$).
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: Debt Service not paid: Arrears Accumulation (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: In the standard presentation of the balance of payments, arrears of interest and amortization--amounts that are past due and unpaid--are recorded as if the amounts had been paid on schedule, and an offsetting entry is made to reflect the associated new, short-term commitments.  Data are in current US dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: Net financial account (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: The net financial account shows net acquisition and disposal of financial assets and liabilities. It measures how net lending to or borrowing from nonresidents is financed, and is conceptually equal to the sum of the balances on the current and capital accounts. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Net primary income (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Net primary income refers to receipts and payments of employee compensation paid to nonresident workers and investment income (receipts and payments on direct investment, portfolio investment, other investments, and receipts on reserve assets). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Net income (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Net income refers to receipts and payments of employee compensation paid to nonresident workers and investment income (receipts and payments on direct investment, portfolio investment, other investments, and receipts on reserve assets). Income derived from the use of intangible assets is recorded under business services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files. World Bank GDP estimates are used for the denominator.

Item2.Name: Net trade in goods and services (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Net trade in goods and services is derived by offsetting imports of goods and services against exports of goods and services. Exports and imports of goods and services comprise all transactions involving a change of ownership of goods and services between residents of one country and the rest of the world. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Net trade in goods (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Net trade in goods is the difference between exports and imports of goods. Trade in services is not included. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Net errors and omissions (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Net errors and omissions constitute a residual category needed to ensure that accounts in the balance of payments statement sum to zero. Net errors and omissions are derived as the balance on the financial account minus the balances on the current and capital accounts. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Capital flows not elsewhere included (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: This item comprises capital transactions not included elsewhere. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: Other capital flows, net (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: The sum of short-term capital, net errors and omissions, and capital transactions not included elsewhere. Data denominated in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: Foreign direct investment, net (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Foreign direct investment are the net inflows of investment to acquire a lasting management interest (10 percent or more of voting stock) in an enterprise operating in an economy other than that of the investor. It is the sum of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, other long-term capital, and short-term capital as shown in the balance of payments. This series shows total net FDI. In BPM6, financial account balances are calculated as the change in assets minus the change in liabilities. Net FDI outflows are assets and net FDI inflows are liabilities. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Foreign direct investment (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Foreign direct investment is net inflows of investment to acquire a lasting management interest (10 percent or more of voting stock) in an enterprise operating in an economy other than that of the investor. It is the sum of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, other long-term capital, and short-term capital as shown in the balance of payments. This series shows total net, that is, net FDI in the reporting economy from foreign sources less net FDI by the reporting economy to the rest of the world. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: Net long-term borrowing (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Net long-term borrowing includes external debt disbursements less repayments due, plus other net long-term inflows. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Other long-term inflows, net (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Other long-term capital comprises the difference between long-term capital, as defined for total long-term capital: excluding reserves and LCFAR, and the similar item reported in IMF balance of payments statistics. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: Private capital flows, total (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Private capital flows consist of net foreign direct investment and portfolio investment. Foreign direct investment is net inflows of investment to acquire a lasting management interest (10 percent or more of voting stock) in an enterprise operating in an economy other than that of the investor. It is the sum of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, other long-term capital, and short-term capital as shown in the balance of payments. The FDI included here is total net, that is, net FDI in the reporting economy from foreign sources less net FDI by the reporting economy to the rest of the world. Portfolio investment covers transactions in equity securities and debt securities. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Private capital flows, total (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Private capital flows consist of net foreign direct investment and portfolio investment. Foreign direct investment is net inflows of investment to acquire a lasting management interest (10 percent or more of voting stock) in an enterprise operating in an economy other than that of the investor. It is the sum of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, other long-term capital, and short-term capital as shown in the balance of payments. The FDI included here is total net, that is, net FDI in the reporting economy from foreign sources less net FDI by the reporting economy to the rest of the world. Portfolio investment covers transactions in equity securities and debt securities.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

Item2.Name: Portfolio Investment, net (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Portfolio investment covers transactions in equity securities and debt securities. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Reserves and related items (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Reserves and related items is the net change in a country's holdings of international reserves resulting from transactions on the current, capital, and financial accounts. Reserve assets are those external assets that are readily available to and controlled by monetary authorities for meeting balance of payments financing needs, and include holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights (SDRs), reserve position in the International Monetary Fund (IMF), and other reserve assets. Also included are net credit and loans from the IMF (excluding reserve position) and total exceptional financing. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Net secondary income (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Secondary income refers to transfers recorded in the balance of payments whenever an economy provides or receives goods, services, income, or financial items without a quid pro quo. All transfers not considered to be capital are current. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Net current transfers (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Net current transfers are recorded in the balance of payments whenever an economy provides or receives goods, services, income, or financial items without a quid pro quo. All transfers not considered to be capital are current. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files. World Bank GDP estimates are used for the denominator.

Item2.Name: Net capital account (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Net capital account records acquisitions and disposals of nonproduced nonfinancial assets, such as land sold to embassies and sales of leases and licenses, as well as capital transfers, including government debt forgiveness. The use of the term capital account in this context is designed to be consistent with the System of National Accounts, which distinguishes between capital transactions and financial transactions. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Official current transfers, net (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Current transfers are recorded in the balance of payments whenever an economy provides or receives goods, services, income, or financial items without a quid pro quo. All transfers not considered to be capital are current. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Private current transfers, net (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Current transfers are recorded in the balance of payments whenever an economy provides or receives goods, services, income, or financial items without a quid pro quo. All transfers not considered to be capital are current. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Workers' remittances, net (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Workers' remittances are current transfers by migrants who are employed or intend to remain employed for more than a year in another economy in which they are considered residents. Some developing countries classify workers' remittances as a factor income receipt (and thus as a component of GNI). The World Bank adheres to international guidelines in defining GNI, and its classification of workers' remittances may therefore differ from national practices. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Grants (disbursements) from new commitments (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Grants (disbursements) from new commitments in current US dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: Agricultural tractors, imports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Agricultural machinery refers to the number of wheel and crawler tractors (excluding garden tractors) in use in agriculture at the end of the calendar year specified or during the first quarter of the following year.  Data are in US$.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Agricultural tractors, imports
Item2.SourceNote: Agricultural machinery refers to the number of wheel and crawler tractors (excluding garden tractors) in use in agriculture at the end of the calendar year specified or during the first quarter of the following year.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Cereal imports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Cereals include wheat, rice, maize, barley, oats, rye, millet, sorghum, buckwheat, and mixed grains. Production data on cereals relate to crops harvested for dry grain only. Cereal crops harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Cereal imports quantity (FAO, tonnes)
Item2.SourceNote: Cereals include wheat, rice, maize, barley, oats, rye, millet, sorghum, buckwheat, and mixed grains. Production data on cereals relate to crops harvested for dry grain only. Cereal crops harvested for hay or harvested green for food, feed, or silage and those used for grazing are excluded.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Forest products exports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Forest products exports.  Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Hazardous pesticides exports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Pesticides refer to insecticides, fungicides, herbicides, disinfectants and any substance or mixture of substances intended for preventing, destroying or controlling any pest, including vectors of human or animal disease, unwanted species of plants or animals causing harm during or otherwise interfering with the production, processing, storage, transport or marketing of food, agricultural commodities, wood and wood products or animal feedstuffs, or substances which may be administered to animals for the control of insects, arachnids or other pests in or on their bodies.  The term includes substances intended for use as a plant growth regulator, defoliant, desiccant or agent for thinning fruit or preventing the premature fall of fruit, and substances applied to crops either before or after harvest to protect the commodity from deterioration during storage and transport.  Pesticide trade is the value of trade covering insecticides, fungicides, herbicides, disinfectants and others, as described by the Harmonised Coding System (HS) code 3808.  Differences between figures given for total exports and total imports at the world level may be due to several factors, e.g. the time lag between the dispatch of goods from exporting country and their arrival in the importing country; the use of different classification of the same product by different countries; or the fact that some countries supply data on general trade while others give data on special trade.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Pesticides exports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Pesticides trade refers to the value of all types of pesticides (put up in forms or packings for retail sale or as preparations or articles), provided to (exports) or received (imported) from the rest of the world. Differences between figures given for total exports and total imports at the world level may be due to several factors, e.g. the time lag between the dispatch of goods from exporting country and their arrival in the importing country; the use of different classification of the same product by different countries; or the fact that some countries supply data on general trade while others give data on special trade.  Pesticides refers to insecticides, fungicides, herbicides, disinfectants and any substance intended for preventing, destroying, attracting, repelling, or controlling any pest including unwanted species of plants or animals during the production, storage, transport, distribution, and processing of food, agricultural commodities, or animal feeds of which may be administered to animals for the control of ectoparasites.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Food exports excluding fish (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Food exports an are expressed in current U.S. dollars at free on board (fob) prices. Excludes fish.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: Grants, excluding technical cooperation (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Grants are defined as legally binding commitments that obligate a specific value of funds available for disbursement for which there is no repayment requirement. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics, and OECD.

Item2.Name: Technical cooperation grants (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Technical cooperation grants include free-standing technical cooperation grants, which are intended to finance the transfer of technical and managerial skills or of technology for the purpose of building up general national capacity without reference to any specific investment projects; and investment-related technical cooperation grants, which are provided to strengthen the capacity to execute specific investment projects. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics, and OECD.

Item2.Name: Total agricultural exports (FAO, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Total agricultural imports are expressed in terms of value.  They cover all movements into the country of the commodity in question during the reference period. They include commercial trade, food aid granted on specific terms, donated quantities and estimates of unrecorded trade.
Item2.SourceOrg: Food and Agriculture Organization, electronic files and web site.

Item2.Name: ICT service exports (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Information and communication technology service exports include computer and communications services (telecommunications and postal and courier services) and information services (computer data and news-related service transactions). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: ICT service exports (% of service exports, BoP)
Item2.SourceNote: Information and communication technology service exports include computer and communications services (telecommunications and postal and courier services) and information services (computer data and news-related service transactions).
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Communications, computer, etc. (% of service exports, BoP)
Item2.SourceNote: Communications, computer, information, and other services cover international telecommunications; computer data; news-related service transactions between residents and nonresidents; construction services; royalties and license fees; miscellaneous business, professional, and technical services; personal, cultural, and recreational services; manufacturing services on physical inputs owned by others; and maintenance and repair services and government services not included elsewhere.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Primary income receipts (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Primary income receipts refer to employee compensation paid to resident workers working abroad and investment income (receipts on direct investment, portfolio investment, other investments, and receipts on reserve assets). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Exports of goods and services (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Exports of goods and services comprise all transactions between residents of a country and the rest of the world involving a change of ownership from residents to nonresidents of general merchandise, net exports of goods under merchanting, nonmonetary gold, and services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Exports of goods, services, income and workers' remittances (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Exports of goods and services are the total value of goods and services exported as well as income and workers' remittances received. Workers' remittances include compensation of employees. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Insurance and financial services (% of service exports, BoP)
Item2.SourceNote: Insurance and financial services cover various types of insurance provided to nonresidents by resident insurance enterprises and vice versa, and financial intermediary and auxiliary services (except those of insurance enterprises and pension funds) exchanged between residents and nonresidents.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Goods exports (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Goods exports refer to all movable goods (including nonmonetary gold and net exports of goods under merchanting) involved in a change of ownership from residents to nonresidents. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Service exports (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Services refer to economic output of intangible commodities that may be produced, transferred, and consumed at the same time. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Charges for the use of intellectual property, receipts (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Charges for the use of intellectual property are payments and receipts between residents and nonresidents for the authorized use of proprietary rights (such as patents, trademarks, copyrights, industrial processes and designs including trade secrets, and franchises) and for the use, through licensing agreements, of produced originals or prototypes (such as copyrights on books and manuscripts, computer software, cinematographic works, and sound recordings) and related rights (such as for live performances and television, cable, or satellite broadcast). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Exports of goods, services and primary income (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Exports of goods, services and primary income is the sum of goods exports, service exports and primary income receipts. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Transport services (% of service exports, BoP)
Item2.SourceNote: Transport covers all transport services (sea, air, land, internal waterway, pipeline, space and electricity transmission) performed by residents of one economy for those of another and involving the carriage of passengers, the movement of goods (freight), rental of carriers with crew, and related support and auxiliary services. Also included are postal and courier services. Excluded are freight insurance (included in insurance services); goods procured in ports by nonresident carriers (included in goods); maintenance and repairs on transport equipment (included in maintenance and repair services n.i.e.); and repairs of railway facilities, harbors, and airfield facilities (included in construction).
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Travel services (% of service exports, BoP)
Item2.SourceNote: Travel covers goods and services acquired from an economy by travelers for their own use during visits of less than one year in that economy for either business or personal purposes. Travel includes local transport (i.e., transport within the economy being visited and provided by a resident of that economy), but excludes international transport (which is included in passenger transport. Travel also excludes goods for resale, which are included in general merchandise.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Foreign direct investment, net inflows in reporting economy (IMF-BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Foreign direct investment is net inflows of investment to acquire a lasting management interest (10 percent or more of voting stock) in an enterprise operating in an economy other than that of the investor. It is the sum of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, other long-term capital, and short-term capital as shown in the balance of payments. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Foreign direct investment, net inflows (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Foreign direct investment refers to direct investment equity flows in the reporting economy. It is the sum of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, and other capital. Direct investment is a category of cross-border investment associated with a resident in one economy having control or a significant degree of influence on the management of an enterprise that is resident in another economy. Ownership of 10 percent or more of the ordinary shares of voting stock is the criterion for determining the existence of a direct investment relationship. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments database, supplemented by data from the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development and official national sources.

Item2.Name: Foreign direct investment, net inflows (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Foreign direct investment are the net inflows of investment to acquire a lasting management interest (10 percent or more of voting stock) in an enterprise operating in an economy other than that of the investor. It is the sum of equity capital, reinvestment of earnings, other long-term capital, and short-term capital as shown in the balance of payments. This series shows net inflows (new investment inflows less disinvestment) in the reporting economy from foreign investors, and is divided by GDP.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics and Balance of Payments databases, World Bank, International Debt Statistics, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

Item2.Name: Primary income on FDI, payments (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Primary income on foreign direct investment covers payments of direct investment income (debit side), which consist of income on equity (dividends, branch profits, and reinvested earnings) and income on the intercompany debt (interest). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Portfolio equity, net inflows (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Portfolio equity includes net inflows from equity securities other than those recorded as direct investment and including shares, stocks, depository receipts (American or global), and direct purchases of shares in local stock markets by foreign investors. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments database, and World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Secondary income receipts (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Secondary income refers to transfers recorded in the balance of payments whenever an economy provides or receives goods, services, income, or financial items without a quid pro quo. All transfers not considered to be capital are current. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Migrant remittance inflows (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Migrants’ remittances are defined as the sum of worker’s remittances,
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff estimates based on the International Monetary Fund's Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook 2008.

Item2.Name: Migrant remittance inflows (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Migrants’ remittances are defined as the sum of worker’s remittances,
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff estimates based on the International Monetary Fund's Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook 2008, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

Item2.Name: Official current transfers, receipts (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Current transfers are recorded in the balance of payments whenever an economy provides or receives goods, services, income, or financial items without a quid pro quo. All transfers not considered to be capital are current. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Official transfers, current and capital (Credit, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Current transfers are recorded in the balance of payments whenever an economy provides or receives goods, services, income, or financial items without a quid pro quo. All transfers not considered to be capital are current. Data are in current U.S. dollars
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: Private current transfers, receipts (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Current transfers are recorded in the balance of payments whenever an economy provides or receives goods, services, income, or financial items without a quid pro quo. All transfers not considered to be capital are current. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Personal transfers, receipts (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Personal transfers consist of all current transfers in cash or in kind made or received by resident households to or from nonresident households. Personal transfers thus include all current transfers between resident and nonresident individuals. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

Item2.Name: Personal remittances, received (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Personal remittances comprise personal transfers and compensation of employees. Personal transfers consist of all current transfers in cash or in kind made or received by resident households to or from nonresident households. Personal transfers thus include all current transfers between resident and nonresident individuals. Compensation of employees refers to the income of border, seasonal, and other short-term workers who are employed in an economy where they are not resident and of residents employed by nonresident entities. Data are the sum of two items defined in the sixth edition of the IMF's Balance of Payments Manual: personal transfers and compensation of employees. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff estimates based on IMF balance of payments data.

Item2.Name: Personal remittances, received (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Personal remittances comprise personal transfers and compensation of employees. Personal transfers consist of all current transfers in cash or in kind made or received by resident households to or from nonresident households. Personal transfers thus include all current transfers between resident and nonresident individuals. Compensation of employees refers to the income of border, seasonal, and other short-term workers who are employed in an economy where they are not resident and of residents employed by nonresident entities. Data are the sum of two items defined in the sixth edition of the IMF's Balance of Payments Manual: personal transfers and compensation of employees.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff estimates based on IMF balance of payments data, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

Item2.Name: Workers' remittances, receipts (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Workers' remittances are current transfers by migrants who are employed or intend to remain employed for more than a year in another economy in which they are considered residents. Some developing countries classify workers' remittances as a factor income receipt (and thus as a component of GNI). The World Bank adheres to international guidelines in defining GNI, and its classification of workers' remittances may therefore differ from national practices. This item shows receipts by the reporting country. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files, and World Bank and OECD GDP estimates.

Item2.SourceNote: Exporter-level information on export transactions - Customs

Item2.Name: 58.Firm Exit Rate
Item2.SourceNote: Exporter-level information on export transactions - Customs

Item2.SourceNote: Exporter-level information on export transactions - Customs

Item2.Name: Control of Corruption: Estimate
Item2.SourceNote:
Control of Corruption captures perceptions of the extent to which public power is exercised for private gain, including both petty and grand forms of corruption, as well as ""capture"" of the state by elites and private interests. 
Estimate gives the country's score on the aggregate indicator, in units of a standard normal distribution, i.e. ranging from approximately -2.5 to 2.5.
Item2.SourceOrg: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

Item2.Name: Control of Corruption: Number of Sources
Item2.SourceNote: Control of Corruption captures perceptions of the extent to which public power is exercised for private gain, including both petty and grand forms of corruption, as well as "capture" of the state by elites and private interests.
Item2.SourceOrg: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

Item2.Name: Control of Corruption: Percentile Rank
Item2.SourceNote: Control of Corruption captures perceptions of the extent to which public power is exercised for private gain, including both petty and grand forms of corruption, as well as "capture" of the state by elites and private interests.
Item2.SourceOrg: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

Item2.Name: Control of Corruption: Standard Error
Item2.SourceNote: Control of Corruption captures perceptions of the extent to which public power is exercised for private gain, including both petty and grand forms of corruption, as well as "capture" of the state by elites and private interests.
Item2.SourceOrg: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

Item2.Name: Meat, chicken, cents/kg, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Meat, sheep (New Zealand), frozen whole carcasses Prime Medium (PM) wholesale, Smithfield, London  beginning January 2006; previously Prime Light (PL)
Item2.SourceOrg: US Department of Agriculture; Bloomberg; World Bank.

Item2.Name: S&P Global Equity Indices (annual % change)
Item2.SourceNote: S&P Global Equity Indices measure the U.S. dollar price change in the stock markets covered by the S&P/IFCI and S&P/Frontier BMI country indices.
Item2.SourceOrg: Standard & Poor's, Global Stock Markets Factbook and supplemental S&P data.

Item2.Name: Market capitalization of listed domestic companies (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Market capitalization (also known as market value) is the share price times the number of shares outstanding (including their several classes) for listed domestic companies. Investment funds, unit trusts, and companies whose only business goal is to hold shares of other listed companies are excluded. Data are end of year values converted to U.S. dollars using corresponding year-end foreign exchange rates.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Federation of Exchanges database.

Item2.Name: Market capitalization of listed domestic companies (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Market capitalization (also known as market value) is the share price times the number of shares outstanding (including their several classes) for listed domestic companies. Investment funds, unit trusts, and companies whose only business goal is to hold shares of other listed companies are excluded. Data are end of year values.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Federation of Exchanges database.

Item2.Name: Listed domestic companies, total
Item2.SourceNote: Listed domestic companies, including foreign companies which are exclusively listed, are those which have shares listed on an exchange at the end of the year. Investment funds, unit trusts, and companies whose only business goal is to hold shares of other listed companies, such as holding companies and investment companies, regardless of their legal status, are excluded. A company with several classes of shares is counted once. Only companies admitted to listing on the exchange are included.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Federation of Exchanges database.

Item2.Name: Stocks traded, total value (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: The value of shares traded is the total number of shares traded, both domestic and foreign, multiplied by their respective matching prices. Figures are single counted (only one side of the transaction is considered). Companies admitted to listing and admitted to trading are included in the data. Data are end of year values converted to U.S. dollars using corresponding year-end foreign exchange rates.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Federation of Exchanges database.

Item2.Name: Stocks traded, total value (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: The value of shares traded is the total number of shares traded, both domestic and foreign, multiplied by their respective matching prices. Figures are single counted (only one side of the transaction is considered). Companies admitted to listing and admitted to trading are included in the data. Data are end of year values.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Federation of Exchanges database.

Item2.Name: Stocks traded, turnover ratio of domestic shares (%)
Item2.SourceNote: Turnover ratio is the value of domestic shares traded divided by their market capitalization. The value is annualized by multiplying the monthly average by 12.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Federation of Exchanges database.

Item2.Name: Coal, Australia, $/mt, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Coal (Australia), thermal, f.o.b. piers, Newcastle/Port Kembla, 6,300 kcal/kg (11,340 btu/lb), less than 0.8%, sulfur 13% ash beginning January 2002; previously 6,667 kcal/kg (12,000 btu/lb), less than 1.0% sulfur, 14%  ash
Item2.SourceOrg: Coal Week International; Coal Week; World Bank.

Item2.Name: Cocoa, cents/kg, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Cocoa (ICCO), International Cocoa Organization daily price, average of  the first three positions on the terminal markets of New York and London, nearest three future trading months.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Cocoa Organization Secretariat; World Bank.

Item2.Name: Coconut oil, $/mt, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Coconut oil (Philippines/Indonesia), bulk, c.i.f. Rotterdam
Item2.SourceOrg: ISTA Mielke GmbH, Oil World; US Department of Agriculture; World Bank.

Item2.Name: Coffee, Arabica, cents/kg, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Coffee (ICO), International Coffee Organization indicator price, other mild Arabicas, average New York and Bremen/Hamburg markets, ex-dock
Item2.SourceOrg: International Coffee Organization; Thomson Reuters Datastream; Complete Coffee Coverage; World Bank.

Item2.Name: Coffee, Robusta, cents/kg, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Coffee (ICO), International Coffee Organization indicator price, Robustas, average New York and Le Havre/Marseilles markets, ex-dock
Item2.SourceOrg: International Coffee Organization; Thomson Reuters Datastream; World Bank.

Item2.Name: Copper, $/mt, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Copper (LME), grade A, minimum 99.9935% purity, cathodes and wire bar shapes, settlement price
Item2.SourceOrg: Platts Metals Week, Engineering and Mining Journal; Thomson Reuters Datastream; World Bank.

Item2.Name: Copra, $/mt, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Copra (Philippines/Indonesia), bulk, c.i.f. N.W. Europe
Item2.SourceOrg: ISTA Mielke GmbH, Oil World; US Department of Agriculture; World Bank.

Item2.Name: Cotton, A Index, cents/kg, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Cotton (Cotton Outlook "CotlookA index"), middling 1-3/32 inch, traded in Far East, C/F beginning 2006; previously Northern Europe, c.i.f.
Item2.SourceOrg: Cotton Outlook; International Cotton Advisory Committee; Liverpool Cotton Services Ltd.; World Bank.

Item2.Name: CPI Price, % y-o-y, median weighted, seas. adj.
Item2.SourceNote: Median inflation rate calculated for geographical aggregates (regions, world, etc) of the annual percent change of the CPI. Data is seasonally adjusted.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.

Item2.Name: CPI Price, nominal, seas. adj.
Item2.SourceNote: The consumer price index reflects the change in prices for the average consumer of a constant basket of consumer goods. Data is in nominal terms and seasonally adjusted.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.

Item2.Name: CPI Price, % y-o-y, nominal, seas. adj.
Item2.SourceNote: The consumer price index reflects the change in prices for the average consumer of a constant basket of consumer goods. Data is in nominal percentage terms, measured on a year-on-year basis, and seasonally adjusted.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.

Item2.Name: Crude oil, Brendt, $/bbl, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Crude oil, U.K. Brent 38` API, f.o.b. U.K ports, spot price
Item2.SourceOrg: Bloomberg; World Bank.

Item2.Name: Crude oil, Dubai, $/bbl, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Crude oil, Dubai Fateh 32` API, f.o.b. Dubai, spot price
Item2.SourceOrg: Bloomberg; World Bank.

Item2.Name: Crude oil, avg, spot, $/bbl, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Crude oil, average spot price of Brent, Dubai and West Texas  Intermediate, equally weighed
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank.

Item2.Name: Crude oil, WTI, $/bbl, current$
Item2.SourceNote: Crude oil, West Texas Intermediate (WTI) 40` API, f.o.b. Midland Texas, spot price
Item2.SourceOrg: Bloomberg; World Bank.

Item2.Name: Net bilateral aid flows from DAC donors, Australia (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Net bilateral aid flows from DAC donors are the net disbursements of official development assistance (ODA) or official aid from the members of the Development Assistance Committee (DAC). Net disbursements are gross disbursements of grants and loans minus repayments of principal on earlier loans. ODA consists of loans made on concessional terms (with a grant element of at least 25 percent, calculated at a rate of discount of 10 percent) and grants made to promote economic development and welfare in countries and territories in the DAC list of ODA recipients. Official aid refers to aid flows from official donors to countries and territories in part II of the DAC list of recipients: more advanced countries of Central and Eastern Europe, the countries of the former Soviet Union, and certain advanced developing countries and territories. Official aid is provided under terms and conditions similar to those for ODA. Part II of the DAC List was abolished in 2005. The collection of data on official aid and other resource flows to Part II countries ended with 2004 data. DAC members are Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Republic of Korea, Luxembourg, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovak Republic, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, United States, and European Union Institutions. Regional aggregates include data for economies not specified elsewhere. World and income group totals include aid not allocated by country or region. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Geographical Distribution of Financial Flows to Developing Countries, Development Co-operation Report, and International Development Statistics database. Data are available online at: www.oecd.org/dac/stats/idsonline.

Net disbursements are gross disbursements of grants and loans minus repayments of principal on earlier loans. ODA consists of loans made on concessional terms (with a grant element of at least 25 percent, calculated at a rate of discount of 10 percent) and grants made to promote economic development and welfare in countries and territories in the DAC list of ODA recipients. Official aid refers to aid flows from official donors to countries and territories in part II of the DAC list of recipients: more advanced countries of Central and Eastern Europe, the countries of the former Soviet Union, and certain advanced developing countries and territories. Official aid is provided under terms and conditions similar to those for ODA. Part II of the DAC List was abolished in 2005. The collection of data on official aid and other resource flows to Part II countries ended with 2004 data. DAC members are Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Iceland, Ireland, Italy, Japan, Republic of Korea, Luxembourg, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovak Republic, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, United Kingdom, United States, and European Union Institutions. Regional aggregates include data for economies not specified elsewhere. World and income group totals include aid not allocated by country or region. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Geographical Distribution of Financial Flows to Developing Countries, Development Co-operation Report, and International Development Statistics database. Data are available online at: www.oecd.org/dac/stats/idsonline.

Item2.Name: Bilateral, sector-allocable ODA to basic social services (% of bilateral ODA commitments)
Item2.SourceNote: Bilateral official development assistance (ODA) commitments are firm obligations, expressed in writing and backed by the necessary funds, undertaken by official bilateral donors to provide specified assistance to a recipient country or a multilateral organization. Bilateral commitments are recorded in the full amount of expected transfer, irrespective of the time required for completing disbursements. Total sector-allocable aid is the sum of aid that can be assigned to specific sectors or multisector activities. Basic social services consists of, primary education, basic life skills for youth and adults and early childhood education, basic health care, basic health infrastructure, basic nutrition, infectious disease control, health education and health personnel development, population policy and administrative management, reproductive health care, family planning, sexually transmitted disease (STD) control including HIV/AIDS, personnel development (population & reproductive health), basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation, and multi-sector aid for basic social services.
Item2.SourceOrg: Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Geographical Distribution of Financial Flows to Developing Countries, Development Co-operation Report, and International Development Statistics database. Data are available online at: www.oecd.org/dac/stats/idsonline.

Item2.Name: Net ODA provided, to the least developed countries (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Net Official development assistance (ODA) comprises grants or loans to developing countries and territories on the OECD/DAC list of aid recipients that are undertaken by the official sector with promotion of economic development and welfare as the main objective and at concessional financial terms. The list of least developed countries (LDCs) has been agreed by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Committee for Development Policy, Economic and Social Council.
Item2.SourceOrg: Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Geographical Distribution of Financial Flows to Developing Countries, Development Co-operation Report, and International Development Statistics database. Data are available online at: www.oecd.org/dac/stats/idsonline.

Item2.Name: Net ODA provided to the least developed countries (% of GNI)
Item2.SourceNote: Net Official development assistance (ODA) comprises grants or loans to developing countries and territories on the OECD/DAC list of aid recipients that are undertaken by the official sector with promotion of economic development and welfare as the main objective and at concessional financial terms. The list of least developed countries (LDCs) has been agreed by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Committee for Development Policy, Economic and Social Council. Series is shown as a share of donors' GNI.
Item2.SourceOrg: Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Geographical Distribution of Financial Flows to Developing Countries, Development Co-operation Report, and International Development Statistics database. Data are available online at: www.oecd.org/dac/stats/idsonline.

Item2.Name: Bilateral ODA commitments that is untied (% of bilateral ODA commitments)
Item2.SourceNote: Bilateral official development assistance (ODA) commitments are firm obligations, expressed in writing and backed by the necessary funds, undertaken by official bilateral donors to provide specified assistance to a recipient country or a multilateral organization. Bilateral commitments are recorded in the full amount of expected transfer, irrespective of the time required for completing disbursements. Untied bilateral official development assistance is assistance from country to country for which the associated goods and services may be fully and freely procured in substantially all countries.
Item2.SourceOrg: Development Assistance Committee of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, Geographical Distribution of Financial Flows to Developing Countries, Development Co-operation Report, and International Development Statistics database.
