Item2.Name: Official exchange rate, LCU per USD, period average
Item2.SourceNote: Official exchange rate refers to the exchange rate determined by national authorities or to the rate determined in the legally sanctioned exchange market. It is calculated as an annual average based on monthly averages (local currency units relative to the U.S. dollar).
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.

Item2.Name: Exchange rate, new LCU per USD extended backward, period average
Item2.SourceNote: Local currency units (LCU) per U.S. dollar, with values prior to the currency's introduction presented in the new currency's terms
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.

Item2.Name: Exchange rate, old LCU per USD extended forward, period average
Item2.SourceNote: Local currency units (LCU) per U.S. dollar, with values after a new currency's introduction presented in the old currency's terms
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.

Item2.Name: Stock Markets, US$
Item2.SourceNote: Local equity market index valued in US$ terms
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.

Item2.Name: Stock Markets, LCU
Item2.SourceNote: Local equity market index valued in local currency unit (LCU) terms
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.

Item2.Name: LT Principal due per balance of payments account (BoP, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Memorandum item - repayments due on outstanding debts.  Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: PPG, bilateral (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Bilateral debt includes loans from governments and their agencies (including central banks), loans from autonomous bodies, and direct loans from official export credit agencies. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in foreign currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, bilateral concessional (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Bilateral debt includes loans from governments and their agencies (including central banks), loans from autonomous bodies, and direct loans from official export credit agencies. Concessional debt is defined as loans with an original grant element of 25 percent or more. The grant element of a loan is the grant equivalent expressed as a percentage of the amount committed. It is used as a measure of the overall cost of borrowing. The grant equivalent of a loan is its commitment (present) value, less the discounted present value of its contractual debt service; conventionally, future service payments are discounted at 10 percent. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal repayments, Total (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Principal repayments, total (AMT, current U.S. dollars).
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank country economists.

Item2.Name: IMF repurchases (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: IMF repurchases are total repayments of outstanding drawings from the General Resources Account during the year specified, excluding repayments due in the reserve tranche. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal repayments on external debt, long-term + IMF (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. This item includes principal repayments on long-term debt and IMF repurchases. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. IMF repurchases are total repayments of outstanding drawings from the General Resources Account during the year specified, excluding repayments due in the reserve tranche. To maintain comparability between data on transactions with the IMF and data on long-term debt, use of IMF credit outstanding at the end of year (stock) is converted to dollars at the SDR exchange rate in effect at the end of year. Repurchases (flows) are converted at the average SDR exchange rate for the year in which transactions take place. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal repayments on external debt, long-term (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Principal repayments on long-term debt are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal repayments on external debt, private nonguaranteed (PNG) (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Private nonguaranteed external debt is an external obligation of a private debtor that is not guaranteed for repayment by a public entity. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal repayments on external debt, public and publicly guaranteed (PPG) (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed long-term debt are aggregated. Public debt is an external obligation of a public debtor, including the national government, a political subdivision (or an agency of either), and autonomous public bodies. Publicly guaranteed debt is an external obligation of a private debtor that is guaranteed for repayment by a public entity. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, IBRD (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed debt outstanding from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) is nonconcessional. Nonconcessional debt excludes loans with an original grant element of 25 percent or more. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, IDA (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed debt outstanding from the International Development Association (IDA) is concessional. Concessional debt is defined as loans with an original grant element of 25 percent or more. The grant element of a loan is the grant equivalent expressed as a percentage of the amount committed. It is used as a measure of the overall cost of borrowing. The grant equivalent of a loan is its commitment (present) value, less the discounted present value of its contractual debt service; conventionally, future service payments are discounted at 10 percent. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, multilateral (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed multilateral loans include loans and credits from the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral and intergovernmental agencies. Excluded are loans from funds administered by an international organization on behalf of a single donor government; these are classified as loans from governments. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, multilateral concessional (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed multilateral loans include loans and credits from the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral and intergovernmental agencies. Excluded are loans from funds administered by an international organization on behalf of a single donor government; these are classified as loans from governments. Concessional debt is defined as loans with an original grant element of 25 percent or more. The grant element of a loan is the grant equivalent expressed as a percentage of the amount committed. It is used as a measure of the overall cost of borrowing. The grant equivalent of a loan is its commitment (present) value, less the discounted present value of its contractual debt service; conventionally, future service payments are discounted at 10 percent. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, official creditors (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed debt from official creditors includes loans from international organizations (multilateral loans) and loans from governments (bilateral loans). Loans from international organization include loans and credits from the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral and intergovernmental agencies. Excluded are loans from funds administered by an international organization on behalf of a single donor government; these are classified as loans from governments. Government loans include loans from governments and their agencies (including central banks), loans from autonomous bodies, and direct loans from official export credit agencies. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, bonds (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed debt from bonds that are either publicly issued or privately placed. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, commercial banks (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed commercial bank loans from private banks and other private financial institutions. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal repayments, PPG and PNG private creditors (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Private nonguaranteed external debt is an external obligation of a private debtor that is not guaranteed for repayment by a public entity. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents and repayable in currency, goods, or services.  Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Global Development Finance.

Item2.Name: PNG, bonds (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Nonguaranteed long-term debt from bonds that are privately placed. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PNG, commercial banks and other creditors (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Nonguaranteed long-term commercial bank loans from private banks and other private financial institutions. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, other private creditors (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed other private credits from manufacturers, exporters, and other suppliers of goods, and bank credits covered by a guarantee of an export credit agency. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, private creditors (AMT, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed debt from private creditors include bonds that are either publicly issued or privately placed; commercial bank loans from private banks and other private financial institutions; and other private credits from manufacturers, exporters, and other suppliers of goods, and bank credits covered by a guarantee of an export credit agency. Principal repayments are actual amounts of principal (amortization) paid by the borrower in currency, goods, or services in the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal arrears, long-term DOD (US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Principal in arrears on long-term debt is defined as principal repayment due but not paid, on a cumulative basis. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal arrears, official creditors (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Principal in arrears on long-term debt is defined as principal repayment due but not paid, on a cumulative basis. Debt from official creditors includes loans from international organizations (multilateral loans) and loans from governments (bilateral loans). Loans from international organization include loans and credits from the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral and intergovernmental agencies. Excluded are loans from funds administered by an international organization on behalf of a single donor government; these are classified as loans from governments. Government loans include loans from governments and their agencies (including central banks), loans from autonomous bodies, and direct loans from official export credit agencies. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal arrears, private creditors (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Principal in arrears on long-term debt is defined as principal repayment due but not paid, on a cumulative basis. Debt from private creditors include bonds that are either publicly issued or privately placed; commercial bank loans from private banks and other private financial institutions; and other private credits from manufacturers, exporters, and other suppliers of goods, and bank credits covered by a guarantee of an export credit agency. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal forgiven (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Principal forgiven is the amount of principal due or in arrears that was written off or forgiven in any given year. It includes debt forgiven within and outside Paris Club agreements, principal forgiven and principal arrears forgiven. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal rescheduled (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Principal rescheduled is the amount of principal due or in arrears that was rescheduled in any given year. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal rescheduled, official (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Principal rescheduled is the amount of principal due or in arrears that was rescheduled in any given year. Debt from official creditors includes loans from international organizations (multilateral loans) and loans from governments (bilateral loans). Loans from international organization include loans and credits from the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral and intergovernmental agencies. Excluded are loans from funds administered by an international organization on behalf of a single donor government; these are classified as loans from governments. Government loans include loans from governments and their agencies (including central banks), loans from autonomous bodies, and direct loans from official export credit agencies. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Principal rescheduled, private (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Principal rescheduled is the amount of principal due or in arrears that was rescheduled in any given year. Debt from private creditors include bonds that are either publicly issued or privately placed; commercial bank loans from private banks and other private financial institutions; and other private credits from manufacturers, exporters, and other suppliers of goods, and bank credits covered by a guarantee of an export credit agency. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Commitments, public and publicly guaranteed (COM, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Commitments are the total amount of long-term loans for which contracts were signed in the year specified; data for private nonguaranteed debt are not available. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Commitments, IBRD (COM, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Commitments (IBRD) are the sum of new commitments on public and publicly guaranteed loans from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Commitments, IDA (COM, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Commitments (IDA) are the sum of new commitments on public and publicly guaranteed loans from the International Development Association (IDA). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Commitments, official creditors (COM, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Commitments are the amount of long-term loans for which contracts were signed in the year specified. Debt from official creditors includes loans from international organizations (multilateral loans) and loans from governments (bilateral loans). Loans from international organization include loans and credits from the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral and intergovernmental agencies. Excluded are loans from funds administered by an international organization on behalf of a single donor government; these are classified as loans from governments. Government loans include loans from governments and their agencies (including central banks), loans from autonomous bodies, and direct loans from official export credit agencies. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Commitments, private creditors (COM, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Commitments are the amount of long-term loans for which contracts were signed in the year specified; data for private nonguaranteed debt are not available. Debt from private creditors include bonds that are either publicly issued or privately placed; commercial bank loans from private banks and other private financial institutions; and other private credits from manufacturers, exporters, and other suppliers of goods, and bank credits covered by a guarantee of an export credit agency. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Currency composition of PPG debt, Deutsche mark (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The percentage of external long-term public and publicly-guaranteed debt contracted in Deutsche marks for the low- and middle-income countries.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Currency composition of PPG debt, Euro (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The percentage of external long-term public and publicly-guaranteed debt contracted in Euros for the low- and middle-income countries.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Currency composition of PPG debt, French franc (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The percentage of external long-term public and publicly-guaranteed debt contracted in French francs for the low- and middle-income countries.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Currency composition of PPG debt, Japanese yen (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The percentage of external long-term public and publicly-guaranteed debt contracted in Japanese yen for the low- and middle-income countries.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Currency composition of PPG debt, Multiple currencies (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The percentage of external long-term public and publicly-guaranteed debt contracted in multiple currencies for the low- and middle-income countries.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Currency composition of PPG debt, all other currencies (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The percentage of external long-term public and publicly-guaranteed debt contracted in all other currencies not specified for the low- and middle-income countries.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Currency composition of PPG debt, SDR (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The percentage of external long-term public and publicly-guaranteed debt contracted in special drawing rights for the low- and middle-income countries.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Currency composition of PPG debt, Swiss franc (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The percentage of external long-term public and publicly-guaranteed debt contracted in Swiss francs for the low- and middle-income countries.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Currency composition of PPG debt, Pound sterling (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The percentage of external long-term public and publicly-guaranteed debt contracted in U.K. pound sterling for the low- and middle-income countries.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Currency composition of PPG debt, U.S. dollars (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The percentage of external long-term public and publicly-guaranteed debt contracted in U.S. dollars for the low- and middle-income countries.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Debt forgiveness or reduction (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Debt forgiveness or reduction shows the change in debt stock due to debt forgiveness or reduction. It is derived by subtracting debt forgiven and debt stock reduction from debt buyback. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, bilateral (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Bilateral debt includes loans from governments and their agencies (including central banks), loans from autonomous bodies, and direct loans from official export credit agencies. Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Disbursements, Bilateral on nonconcessional terms (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Bilateral debt includes loans from governments and their agencies (including central banks), loans from autonomous bodies, and direct loans from official export credit agencies. Concessional debt is defined as loans with an original grant element of 25 percent or more. The grant equivalent of a loan is its commitment (present) value, less the discounted present value of its contractual debt service; conventionally, future service payments are discounted at 10 percent. The grant element of a loan is the grant equivalent expressed as a percentage of the amount committed. It is used as a measure of the overall cost of borrowing. Disbursements are drawings on loan commitments during the year specified.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Global Development Finance.

Item2.Name: PPG, bilateral concessional (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Bilateral debt includes loans from governments and their agencies (including central banks), loans from autonomous bodies, and direct loans from official export credit agencies. Concessional debt is defined as loans with an original grant element of 25 percent or more. The grant element of a loan is the grant equivalent expressed as a percentage of the amount committed. It is used as a measure of the overall cost of borrowing. The grant equivalent of a loan is its commitment (present) value, less the discounted present value of its contractual debt service; conventionally, future service payments are discounted at 10 percent. Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Disbursements, Total (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Disbursements are drawings on loan commitments during the year specified. This item includes disbursements on long-term and short-term debt and IMF repurchases. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents and repayable in currency, goods, or services. IMF purchases are total drawings on the General Resources Account of the IMF during the year specified, excluding drawings in the reserve tranche. To maintain comparability between data on transactions with the IMF and data on long-term debt, use of IMF credit outstanding at the end of year (stock) is converted to dollars at the SDR exchange rate in effect at the end of year. Purchases are converted at the average SDR exchange rate for the year in which transactions take place.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Global Development Finance.

Item2.Name: IMF purchases (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: IMF purchases are total drawings on the General Resources Account of the IMF during the year specified, excluding drawings in the reserve tranche. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Disbursements on external debt, long-term + IMF (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. This item includes disbursements on long-term debt and IMF purchases. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. IMF purchases are total drawings on the General Resources Account of the IMF during the year specified, excluding drawings in the reserve tranche. To maintain comparability between data on transactions with the IMF and data on long-term debt, use of IMF credit outstanding at the end of year (stock) is converted to dollars at the SDR exchange rate in effect at the end of year. Purchases are converted at the average SDR exchange rate for the year in which transactions take place. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Disbursements on external debt, long-term (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Disbursements on long-term debt are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Disbursements on external debt, private nonguaranteed (PNG) (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Private nonguaranteed external debt is an external obligation of a private debtor that is not guaranteed for repayment by a public entity. Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Disbursements on external debt, public and publicly guaranteed (PPG) (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed long-term debt are aggregated. Public debt is an external obligation of a public debtor, including the national government, a political subdivision (or an agency of either), and autonomous public bodies. Publicly guaranteed debt is an external obligation of a private debtor that is guaranteed for repayment by a public entity. Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents by residents of an economy and repayable in currency, goods, or services. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Disbursements, Short-term (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Short-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original maturity of one year or less. Available data permit no distinction between public and private nonguaranteed short-term debt.  Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Global Development Finance.

Item2.Name: IDA grants (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: IDA grants are net disbursements of grants from the International Development Association (IDA). Data are in current U.S. dollars. Regional allocations are included in aggregate data.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, IBRD (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed debt outstanding from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) is nonconcessional. Nonconcessional debt excludes loans with an original grant element of 25 percent or more. Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed debt outstanding from the International Development Association (IDA) is concessional. Concessional debt is defined as loans with an original grant element of 25 percent or more. The grant element of a loan is the grant equivalent expressed as a percentage of the amount committed. It is used as a measure of the overall cost of borrowing. The grant equivalent of a loan is its commitment (present) value, less the discounted present value of its contractual debt service; conventionally, future service payments are discounted at 10 percent. Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, multilateral (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed multilateral loans include loans and credits from the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral and intergovernmental agencies. Excluded are loans from funds administered by an international organization on behalf of a single donor government; these are classified as loans from governments. Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.

Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed multilateral loans include loans and credits from the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral and intergovernmental agencies. Excluded are loans from funds administered by an international organization on behalf of a single donor government. Disbursements are drawings on loan commitments during the year specified.  Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Global Development Finance.

Item2.Name: PPG, multilateral concessional (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed multilateral loans include loans and credits from the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral and intergovernmental agencies. Excluded are loans from funds administered by an international organization on behalf of a single donor government; these are classified as loans from governments. Concessional debt is defined as loans with an original grant element of 25 percent or more. The grant element of a loan is the grant equivalent expressed as a percentage of the amount committed. It is used as a measure of the overall cost of borrowing. The grant equivalent of a loan is its commitment (present) value, less the discounted present value of its contractual debt service; conventionally, future service payments are discounted at 10 percent. Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, official creditors (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed debt from official creditors includes loans from international organizations (multilateral loans) and loans from governments (bilateral loans). Loans from international organization include loans and credits from the World Bank, regional development banks, and other multilateral and intergovernmental agencies. Excluded are loans from funds administered by an international organization on behalf of a single donor government; these are classified as loans from governments. Government loans include loans from governments and their agencies (including central banks), loans from autonomous bodies, and direct loans from official export credit agencies. Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, bonds (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed debt from bonds that are either publicly issued or privately placed. Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: PPG, commercial banks (DIS, current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed commercial bank loans from private banks and other private financial institutions. Disbursements are drawings by the borrower on loan commitments during the year specified. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, International Debt Statistics.

Item2.Name: Disbursements, PPG and PNG private creditors (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Private nonguaranteed external debt is an external obligation of a private debtor that is not guaranteed for repayment by a public entity. Disbursements are drawings on loan commitments during the year specified. Long-term external debt is defined as debt that has an original or extended maturity of more than one year and that is owed to nonresidents and repayable in currency, goods, or services.  Public and publicly guaranteed debt from private creditors include bonds that are either publicly issued or privately placed; commercial bank loans from private banks and other private financial institutions; and private credits from manufacturers, exporters, and other suppliers of goods, and bank credits covered by a guarantee of an export credit agency.   Disbursements are drawings on loan commitments during the year specified.

Item2.Name: PNG, bonds (DIS, current US$)

Item2.SourceNote: Public and publicly guaranteed other private credits from manufacturers, exporters, and other suppliers of goods, and bank credits covered by a guarantee of an export credit agency.
