Item2.Name: HIV positive pregnant women receiving antiretrovirals, using WHO/UNAIDS methodology (%; high estimate)
Item2.SourceNote: Percentage of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission.  Numerator: Number of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals during the last 12 months to reduce mother-to-child transmission.  Denominator: Estimated number of HIV-infected pregnant women in the last 12 months.  Ranges are presented for countries with low and concentrated epidemics.  The purpose of this indicator is to assess progress in preventing vertical transmission of HIV.  All data reflect values representing 12 month period ending December 2007 which have been reconciled between reporting country and UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF, unless otherwise noted.  All analysis of this indicator, including quoted country figures, reflect numerators which have gone through a tri agency reconciliation (UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF) process and denominators which have been estimated directly from the UNAIDS/WHO Reference group on Estimates, Modelling and Projections methodology (Spectrum).  The reconciliation process ensured all agencies reported the same country endorsed figure which was the most recent and met the definition of HIV-infected women receiving antiretroviral drugs over the last 12 months, and thus reflect a full year. Every effort was made in cases of discrepancy across the three agencies to obtain approval from the country on a final indicator value.
Item2.SourceOrg: http://data.unaids.org/pub/GlobalReport/2008/

Item2.Name: HIV positive pregnant women receiving antiretrovirals, using WHO/UNAIDS methodology (%; low estimate)
Item2.SourceNote: Percentage of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission.  Numerator: Number of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals during the last 12 months to reduce mother-to-child transmission.  Denominator: Estimated number of HIV-infected pregnant women in the last 12 months.  Ranges are presented for countries with low and concentrated epidemics.  The purpose of this indicator is to assess progress in preventing vertical transmission of HIV.  All data reflect values representing 12 month period ending December 2007 which have been reconciled between reporting country and UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF, unless otherwise noted.  All analysis of this indicator, including quoted country figures, reflect numerators which have gone through a tri agency reconciliation (UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF) process and denominators which have been estimated directly from the UNAIDS/WHO Reference group on Estimates, Modelling and Projections methodology (Spectrum).  The reconciliation process ensured all agencies reported the same country endorsed figure which was the most recent and met the definition of HIV-infected women receiving antiretroviral drugs over the last 12 months, and thus reflect a full year. Every effort was made in cases of discrepancy across the three agencies to obtain approval from the country on a final indicator value.
Item2.SourceOrg: http://data.unaids.org/pub/GlobalReport/2008/

Item2.Name: Number of HIV positive pregnant women receiving antiretrovirals
Item2.SourceNote: Number of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals during the last 12 months to reduce mother-to-child transmission.  The purpose of this indicator is to assess progress in preventing vertical transmission of HIV.
Item2.SourceOrg: http://data.unaids.org/pub/GlobalReport/2008/

Item2.Name: HIV positive pregnant women receiving antiretrovirals, using WHO/UNAIDS methodology (%)
Item2.SourceNote: Percentage of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission.  Numerator: Number of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals during the last 12 months to reduce mother-to-child transmission.  Denominator: Estimated number of HIV-infected pregnant women in the last 12 months.  The purpose of this indicator is to assess progress in preventing vertical transmission of HIV.  All data reflect values representing 12 month period ending December 2007 which have been reconciled between reporting country and UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF, unless otherwise noted.  All analysis of this indicator, including quoted country figures, reflect numerators which have gone through a tri agency reconciliation (UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF) process and denominators which have been estimated directly from the UNAIDS/WHO Reference group on Estimates, Modelling and Projections methodology (Spectrum).  The reconciliation process ensured all agencies reported the same country endorsed figure which was the most recent and met the definition of HIV-infected women receiving antiretroviral drugs over the last 12 months, and thus reflect a full year. Every effort was made in cases of discrepancy across the three agencies to obtain approval from the country on a final indicator value.
Item2.SourceOrg: http://data.unaids.org/pub/GlobalReport/2008/

Item2.Name: Adults (ages 15+) and children (0-14 years) living with HIV
Item2.SourceNote: Adults and children living with HIV refers to the number of people ages 0-49 (adult ages 15-49 and children ages 0-14) who are infected with HIV.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNAIDS estimates.

Item2.Name: People living with HIV/AIDS, total (high estimate)
Item2.SourceNote: Estimated total number of people with HIV/AIDS is the number of people living with HIV. Depending on the reliability of the data available, there may be more or less uncertainty surrounding each estimate.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

Item2.Name: People living with HIV/AIDS, total (low estimate)
Item2.SourceNote: Estimated total number of people with HIV/AIDS is the number of people living with HIV. Depending on the reliability of the data available, there may be more or less uncertainty surrounding each estimate.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

Item2.Name: People living with HIV/AIDS, total
Item2.SourceNote: Estimated total number of people with HIV/AIDS is the number of people living with HIV. Depending on the reliability of the data available, there may be more or less uncertainty surrounding each estimate.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

Item2.Name: Immunization, HepB3 (% of one-year-old children)
Item2.SourceNote: Child immunization rate, hepatitis B is the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized after three doses.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

Item2.Name: Immunization, Hib3 (% of children ages 12-23 months)
Item2.SourceNote: Child immunization measures the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized against Hib3 after receiving three doses of Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/

Item2.Name: Immunization, BCG (% of one-year-old children)
Item2.SourceNote: Child immunization rate, BCG is the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey for BCG. A child is considered adequately immunized after one dose.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

Item2.Name: Immunization, DPT (% of children ages 12-23 months)
Item2.SourceNote: Child immunization measures the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized against diphtheria, pertussis (or whooping cough), and tetanus (DPT) after receiving three doses of vaccine.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization/monitoring_surveillance/en/).

Item2.Name: Immunization, measles (% of children ages 12-23 months)
Item2.SourceNote: Child immunization measures the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized against measles after receiving one dose of vaccine.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization/monitoring_surveillance/en/).

Item2.Name: Immunization, Pol3 (% of one-year-old children)
Item2.SourceNote: Child immunization rate, Polio is the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized after three doses.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

Item2.Name: Hospital beds (per 1,000 people)
Item2.SourceNote: Hospital beds include inpatient beds available in public, private, general, and specialized hospitals and rehabilitation centers. In most cases beds for both acute and chronic care are included.
Item2.SourceOrg: Data are from the World Health Organization, supplemented by country data.

Item2.Name: Community health workers (per 1,000 people)
Item2.SourceNote: Community health workers include various types of community health aides, many with country-specific occupational titles such as community health officers, community health-education workers, family health workers, lady health visitors and health extension package workers.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization's Global Health Workforce Statistics, OECD, supplemented by country data.

Item2.Name: Nurses and midwives (per 1,000 people)
Item2.SourceNote: Nurses and midwives include professional nurses, professional midwives, auxiliary nurses, auxiliary midwives, enrolled nurses, enrolled midwives and other associated personnel, such as dental nurses and primary care nurses.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization's Global Health Workforce Statistics, OECD, supplemented by country data.

Item2.Name: Physicians (per 1,000 people)
Item2.SourceNote: Physicians include generalist and specialist medical practitioners.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization's Global Health Workforce Statistics, OECD, supplemented by country data.

Item2.Name: Reported clinical malaria cases (total)
Item2.SourceNote: Number of clinical malaria cases reported are the sum of cases confirmed by slide examination or RDT and probable and unconfirmed cases (cases that were not tested but treated as malaria). NMCPs often collect data on the number of suspected cases, those t
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Malaria Programme (http://www.who.int/malaria/world_malaria_report_2009/all_mal2009_annexes.pdf)

Item2.Name: Deaths among children under five years of age due to malaria (%)
Item2.SourceNote: "Malaria mortality is the percentage of deaths due to malaria among children under five years.  Malaria was the underlying cause of death, that is, the disease which initiated the train of morbid events leading directly to death. This is the distribution of main causes of death among children aged < 5 years, expressed as percentage of total deaths. "
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organisation.

Item2.Name: Reported malaria deaths (total)
Item2.SourceNote: Reported malaria deaths include all deaths in health facilities that are attributed to malaria, whether or not confirmed by microscopy or by RDT.   Deaths reported before 2000 can be probable and confirmed or only confirmed deaths depending on the country
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Malaria Programme (http://www.who.int/malaria/world_malaria_report_2009/all_mal2009_annexes.pdf)

Item2.Name: Households with one or more insect-treated mosquito net (%)
Item2.SourceNote: Percentage of households owning at least one insecticide-treated bednet (ITN).
Item2.SourceOrg: DHS, MICS, MIS or MoH surveys.

Item2.Name: Use of insecticide-treated bed nets (% of under-5 population)
Item2.SourceNote: Use of insecticide-treated bed nets refers to the percentage of children under age five who slept under an insecticide-treated bednet to prevent malaria.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Pregnant women who took at least 2 doses of intermittent preventative treatment (%)
Item2.SourceNote: Percentage of pregnant women reporting to have received IPT (intermittent preventive treatment; 2 or more doses).
Item2.SourceOrg: DHS, MICS, MIS or MoH surveys.

Item2.Name: Use of any antimalarial drug
Item2.SourceNote: Demographic and Health Surveys.
Item2.SourceOrg: Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Use of Intermittent Preventive Treatment of malaria, 2+ doses of SP/Fansidar (% of pregnant women)
Item2.SourceNote: Percentage of women with a live birth in the recent years preceding the survey who received 2+ doses of sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (SP/Fansidar), at least one during an antenatal care visit. Intermittent Preventive Treatment (IPT) is preventive treatment with SP/Fansidar during an antenatal care (ANC) visit treatment with a dose of sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (SP/Fansidar) to pregnant women at each scheduled antenatal visit after the first trimester, but not more frequently than once a month.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF Childinfo, Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys, Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Children with fever receiving antimalarial drugs (% of children under age 5 with fever)
Item2.SourceNote: Malaria treatment refers to the percentage of children under age five who were ill with fever in the last two weeks and received any appropriate (locally defined) anti-malarial drugs.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Number of maternal deaths
Item2.SourceNote: A maternal death refers to the death of a woman while pregnant or within 42 days of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of the duration and site of the pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, The World Bank, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 1990 to 2015. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2015

Item2.Name: Lifetime risk of maternal death (1 in: rate varies by country)
Item2.SourceNote: Life time risk of maternal death is the probability that a 15-year-old female will die eventually from a maternal cause assuming that current levels of fertility and mortality (including maternal mortality) do not change in the future, taking into account competing causes of death.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, The World Bank, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 1990 to 2015. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2015

Item2.Name: Lifetime risk of maternal death (%)
Item2.SourceNote: Life time risk of maternal death is the probability that a 15-year-old female will die eventually from a maternal cause assuming that current levels of fertility and mortality (including maternal mortality) do not change in the future, taking into account competing causes of death.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, The World Bank, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 1990 to 2015. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2015

Item2.Name: Prevalence of anemia among pregnant women (%)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of anemia, pregnant women, is the percentage of pregnant women whose hemoglobin level is less than 110 grams per liter at sea level.
Item2.SourceOrg: 1. WHO. Global anemia prevalence and trends 1995-2011. Geneva: World Health Organization; forthcoming.  2. Stevens GA, Finucane MM, De-Regil LM, et al. Global, regional, and national trends in hemoglobin concentration and prevalence of total and severe anemia in children and pregnant and non-pregnant women for 1995-2011: a systematic analysis of population-representative data. The Lancet Global Health 2013; 1(1): e16-e25.

Item2.Name: Antiretroviral therapy coverage (% of pregnant women living with HIV)
Item2.SourceNote: The percentage of HIV-positive pregnant women who received antiretroviral medicine during the past 12 months to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission during pregnancy and delivery.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNAIDS estimates.

Item2.Name: Smoking prevalence, females (% of adults)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of smoking, female is the percentage of women ages 15 and over who smoke any form of tobacco, including cigarettes, cigars, pipes or any other smoked tobacco products. Data include daily and non-daily or occasional smoking.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

Item2.Name: Smoking prevalence, males (% of adults)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of smoking, male is the percentage of men ages 15 and over who smoke any form of tobacco, including cigarettes, cigars, pipes or any other smoked tobacco products. Data include daily and non-daily or occasional smoking.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Health Observatory Data Repository (http://apps.who.int/ghodata/).

Item2.Name: Improved sanitation facilities (% of population with access)
Item2.SourceNote: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population using improved sanitation facilities. Improved sanitation facilities are likely to ensure hygienic separation of human excreta from human contact. They include flush/pour flush (to piped sewer system, septic tank, pit latrine), ventilated improved pit (VIP) latrine, pit latrine with slab, and composting toilet.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

Item2.Name: Improved sanitation facilities, rural (% of rural population with access)
Item2.SourceNote: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population using improved sanitation facilities. Improved sanitation facilities are likely to ensure hygienic separation of human excreta from human contact. They include flush/pour flush (to piped sewer system, septic tank, pit latrine), ventilated improved pit (VIP) latrine, pit latrine with slab, and composting toilet.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

Item2.Name: Improved sanitation facilities, urban (% of urban population with access)
Item2.SourceNote: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population using improved sanitation facilities. Improved sanitation facilities are likely to ensure hygienic separation of human excreta from human contact. They include flush/pour flush (to piped sewer system, septic tank, pit latrine), ventilated improved pit (VIP) latrine, pit latrine with slab, and composting toilet.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

Item2.Name: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care of at least four visits (% of pregnant women)
Item2.SourceNote: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care (%)
Item2.SourceNote: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care are the percentage of women attended at least once during pregnancy by skilled health personnel for reasons related to pregnancy.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: ARI treatment (% of children under 5 taken to a health provider)
Item2.SourceNote: Children with acute respiratory infection (ARI) who are taken to a health provider refers to the percentage of children under age five with ARI in the last two weeks who were taken to an appropriate health provider, including hospital, health center, dispensary, village health worker, clinic, and private physician.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Exclusive breastfeeding (% of children under 6 months)
Item2.SourceNote: Exclusive breastfeeding refers to the percentage of children less than six months old who are fed breast milk alone (no other liquids) in the past 24 hours.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Births attended by skilled health staff (% of total)
Item2.SourceNote: Births attended by skilled health staff are the percentage of deliveries attended by personnel trained to give the necessary supervision, care, and advice to women during pregnancy, labor, and the postpartum period; to conduct deliveries on their own; and to care for newborns.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Low-birthweight babies (% of births)
Item2.SourceNote: Low-birthweight babies are newborns weighing less than 2,500 grams, with the measurement taken within the first hours of life, before significant postnatal weight loss has occurred.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Diabetes prevalence (% of population ages 20 to 79)
Item2.SourceNote: Diabetes prevalence refers to the percentage of people ages 20-79 who have type 1 or type 2 diabetes.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Diabetes Federation, Diabetes Atlas.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of underweight, weight for age, female (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of underweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of underweight, weight for age, male (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of underweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of underweight, weight for age (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of underweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries. Adjusted, comparable data are available at http://www.who.int/nutgrowthdb/en. Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

Item2.Name: Malaria cases reported
Item2.SourceNote: Reported cases of malaria are the sum of confirmed cases of malaria (confirmed by slide examination or RDT) and probable (unconfirmed) cases of malaria (cases that were not tested but treated as malaria). Predominant type of statistics: unadjusted.

Item2.Name: Maternal mortality ratio (modeled estimate, per 100,000 live births)
Item2.SourceNote: Maternal mortality ratio is the number of women who die from pregnancy-related causes while pregnant or within 42 days of pregnancy termination per 100,000 live births. The data are estimated with a regression model using information on the proportion of maternal deaths among non-AIDS deaths in women ages 15-49, fertility, birth attendants, and GDP.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, The World Bank, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 1990 to 2015. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2015

Item2.Name: Maternal mortality ratio (national estimate, per 100,000 live births)
Item2.SourceNote: Maternal mortality ratio is the number of women who die from pregnancy-related causes while pregnant or within 42 days of pregnancy termination per 100,000 live births.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Diarrhea treatment (% of children under 5 receiving oral rehydration and continued feeding)
Item2.SourceNote: Children with diarrhea who received oral rehydration and continued feeding refer to the percentage of children under age five with diarrhea in the two weeks prior to the survey who received either oral rehydration therapy or increased fluids, with continued feeding.
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Diarrhea treatment (% of children under 5 who received ORS packet)
Item2.SourceNote: Percentage of children under age 5 with diarrhea in the two weeks preceding the survey who received oral rehydration salts (ORS packets or pre-packaged ORS fluids).
Item2.SourceOrg: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of overweight, female (% of female population ages 15+)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of overweight (% of population ages 15+), female
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization

Item2.Name: Prevalence of overweight, male (% of male population ages 15+)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of overweight (% of population ages 15+), male
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization

Item2.Name: Prevalence of overweight, weight for height, female (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of overweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations above the median for the international reference population of the corresponding age as established by the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of overweight, weight for height, male (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of overweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations above the median for the international reference population of the corresponding age as established by the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of overweight, weight for height (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of overweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations above the median for the international reference population of the corresponding age as established by the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries. Adjusted, comparable data are available at http://www.who.int/nutgrowthdb/en. Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of stunting, height for age, female (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of stunting is the percentage of children under age 5 whose height for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of stunting, height for age, male (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of stunting is the percentage of children under age 5 whose height for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of stunting, height for age (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of stunting is the percentage of children under age 5 whose height for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries. Adjusted, comparable data are available at http://www.who.int/nutgrowthdb/en. Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of wasting, weight for height, female (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Wasting prevalence is the proportion of children under five whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of wasting, weight for height, male (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Wasting prevalence is the proportion of children under five whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of wasting, weight for height (% of children under 5)
Item2.SourceNote: Wasting prevalence is the proportion of children under five whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries. Adjusted, comparable data are available at http://www.who.int/nutgrowthdb/en. Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

Item2.Name: Tuberculosis treatment success rate (% of new cases)
Item2.SourceNote: Tuberculosis treatment success rate is the percentage of all new tuberculosis cases (or new and relapse cases for some countries) registered under a national tuberculosis control programme in a given year that successfully completed treatment, with or without bacteriological evidence of success ("cured" and "treatment completed" respectively).
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

Item2.Name: Tuberculosis case detection rate (%, all forms)
Item2.SourceNote: Tuberculosis case detection rate (all forms) is the number of new and relapse tuberculosis cases notified to WHO in a given year, divided by WHO's estimate of the number of incident tuberculosis cases for the same year, expressed as a percentage. Estimates for all years are recalculated as new information becomes available and techniques are refined, so they may differ from those published previously.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Report.

Item2.Name: Incidence of tuberculosis (per 100,000 people)
Item2.SourceNote: Incidence of tuberculosis is the estimated number of new and relapse tuberculosis cases arising in a given year, expressed as the rate per 100,000 population. All forms of TB are included, including cases in people living with HIV. Estimates for all years are recalculated as new information becomes available and techniques are refined, so they may differ from those published previously.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Report.

Item2.Name: Incidence of tuberculosis, high uncertainty bound (per 100,000 people)
Item2.SourceNote: Incidence of tuberculosis is the estimated number of new pulmonary, smear positive, and extra-pulmonary tuberculosis cases.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

Item2.Name: Incidence of tuberculosis, low uncertainty bound (per 100,000 people)
Item2.SourceNote: Incidence of tuberculosis is the estimated number of new pulmonary, smear positive, and extra-pulmonary tuberculosis cases.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

Item2.Name: Tuberculosis death rate (per 100,000 people)
Item2.SourceNote: Tuberculosis death rate is the estimated number of deaths from tuberculosis among HIV-negative people, expressed as the rate per 100,000 population.  Estimates for all years are recalculated as new information becomes available and techniques are refined, so they may differ from those published previously.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Report.

Item2.Name: Deaths due to tuberculosis among HIV-negative people, high uncertainty bound (per 100,000 population)
Item2.SourceNote: The estimated number of deaths attributable to tuberculosis (TB) in a given time period.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

Item2.Name: Deaths due to tuberculosis among HIV-negative people, low uncertainty bound (per 100,000 population)
Item2.SourceNote: The estimated number of deaths attributable to tuberculosis (TB) in a given time period.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

Item2.Name: Prevalence of tuberculosis (per 100,000 population)
Item2.SourceNote: Prevalence of tuberculosis is the estimated number of TB cases (all forms) at a given point in time, expressed as the rate per 100,000 population. Estimates for all years are recalculated as new information becomes available and techniques are refined, so they may differ from those published previously.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Report.

Item2.Name: Tuberculosis prevalence rate, high uncertainty bound (per 1000,000 population, WHO)
Item2.SourceNote: The number of cases of tuberculosis (all forms) in a population at a given point in time (the middle of the calendar year), expressed as the rate per 100 000 population. It is sometimes referred to as "point prevalence" high uncertainty bound. Estimates include cases of TB in people with HIV.  Published values are rounded to three significant figures. Uncertainty bounds are provided in addition to best estimates.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

Item2.Name: Tuberculosis prevalence rate, low uncertainty bound (per 1000,000 population, WHO)
Item2.SourceNote: The number of cases of tuberculosis (all forms) in a population at a given point in time (the middle of the calendar year), expressed as the rate per 100 000 population. It is sometimes referred to as "point prevalence" low uncertainty bound. Estimates include cases of TB in people with HIV.  Published values are rounded to three significant figures. Uncertainty bounds are provided in addition to best estimates.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

Item2.Name: Newborns protected against tetanus (%)
Item2.SourceNote: Newborns protected against tetanus are the percentage of births by women of child-bearing age who are immunized against tetanus.
Item2.SourceOrg: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization/monitoring_surveillance/en/).

Item2.Name: External resources for health (% of total expenditure on health)
Item2.SourceNote: External resources for health are funds or services in kind that are provided by entities not part of the country in question. The resources may come from international organizations, other countries through bilateral arrangements, or foreign nongovernmental organizations. These resources are part of total health expenditure.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

Item2.Name: Out-of-pocket health expenditure (% of total expenditure on health)
Item2.SourceNote: Out of pocket expenditure is any direct outlay by households, including gratuities and in-kind payments, to health practitioners and suppliers of pharmaceuticals, therapeutic appliances, and other goods and services whose primary intent is to contribute to the restoration or enhancement of the health status of individuals or population groups. It is a part of private health expenditure.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

Item2.Name: Out-of-pocket health expenditure (% of private expenditure on health)
Item2.SourceNote: Out of pocket expenditure is any direct outlay by households, including gratuities and in-kind payments, to health practitioners and suppliers of pharmaceuticals, therapeutic appliances, and other goods and services whose primary intent is to contribute to the restoration or enhancement of the health status of individuals or population groups. It is a part of private health expenditure.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

Item2.Name: Health expenditure per capita (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditures as a ratio of total population. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

Item2.Name: Government health expenditure per capita (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: General government expenditure corresponds to the consolidated outlays of all levels of government: territorial authorities (Central/Federal Government, Provincial/Regional/State/District authorities, Municipal/ Local governments), social security institutions and extra budgetary funds, including capital outlays. It is provided by the Central Bank/Ministry of Finance to the International Monetary Fund or by the United Nations Statistics Department.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization (http://www.who.int/nha/country/en/)

Item2.Name: Health expenditure per capita, PPP (constant 2011 international $)
Item2.SourceNote: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditures as a ratio of total population. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation. Data are in international dollars converted using 2011 purchasing power parity (PPP) rates.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

Item2.Name: Private prepaid plans (% of private expenditure on health)
Item2.SourceNote: Prepaid and risk-pooling plans are the expenditure on health by private insurance institutions.  Private insurance enrolment may be contractual or voluntary, and conditions and benefits or basket of benefits are agreed on a voluntary basis between the insurance agent and the beneficiaries.  They are thus not controlled by government units for the purpose of providing social benefits to members.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization (http://www.who.int/nha/country/en/)

Item2.Name: Health expenditure, private (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Private health expenditure includes direct household (out-of-pocket) spending, private insurance, charitable donations, and direct service payments by private corporations.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

Item2.Name: Health expenditure, public (% of total health expenditure)
Item2.SourceNote: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets, external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations), and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds. Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditure. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

Item2.Name: Health expenditure, public (% of government expenditure)
Item2.SourceNote: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets, external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations), and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

Item2.Name: Health expenditure, public (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets, external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations), and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

Item2.Name: Social Security expenditure on health (% government expenditure on health)
Item2.SourceNote: Social security funds comprise the expenditure on health by social security institutions. Social security or national health insurance schemes are imposed and controlled by government units for the purpose of providing social benefits to members of the community as a whole or to particular segments of the community. They include direct outlays to medical care providers and to suppliers of medical goods as well as reimbursements to households and the supply of services in kind to the enrollees.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization (http://www.who.int/nha/country/en/)

Item2.Name: Health expenditure (current US$)
Item2.SourceNote: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

Item2.Name: Health expenditure, total (% of GDP)
Item2.SourceNote: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditure. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Health Organization Global Health Expenditure database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

Item2.Name: Poverty headcount ratio at $2.5 a day (PPP) (% of population)
Item2.SourceNote: Population below $2.5 a day is the percentage of the population living on less than $2.5 a day at 2005 international prices.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

Item2.Name: Poverty headcount ratio at $3.10 a day (2011 PPP) (% of population)
Item2.SourceNote: Poverty headcount ratio at $3.10 a day is the percentage of the population living on less than $3.10 a day at 2011 international prices. As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions. Note: five countries -- Bangladesh, Cabo Verde, Cambodia, Jordan, and Lao PDR -- use the 2005 PPP conversion factors and corresponding $1.25 a day and $2 a day poverty lines. This is due to the large deviations in the rate of change in PPP factors relative to the rate of change in domestic consumer price indexes. See Box 1.1 in the Global Monitoring Report 2015/2016 (http://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/global-monitoring-report) for a detailed explanation.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

Item2.SourceNote: Poverty headcount ratio at $1.90 a day is the percentage of the population living on less than $1.90 a day at 2011 international prices. As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions. Note: five countries -- Bangladesh, Cabo Verde, Cambodia, Jordan, and Lao PDR -- use the 2005 PPP conversion factors and corresponding $1.25 a day and $2 a day poverty lines. This is due to the large deviations in the rate of change in PPP factors relative to the rate of change in domestic consumer price indexes. See Box 1.1 in the Global Monitoring Report 2015/2016 (http://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/global-monitoring-report) for a detailed explanation.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Item2.Name: Poverty gap at $3.10 a day (2011 PPP) (%)
Item2.SourceNote: Poverty gap at $3.10 a day (2011 PPP) is the mean shortfall in income or consumption from the poverty line $3.10 a day (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall), expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence. As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions. Note: five countries -- Bangladesh, Cabo Verde, Cambodia, Jordan, and Lao PDR -- use the 2005 PPP conversion factors and corresponding $1.25 a day and $2 a day poverty lines. This is due to the large deviations in the rate of change in PPP factors relative to the rate of change in domestic consumer price indexes. See Box 1.1 in the Global Monitoring Report 2015/2016 (http://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/global-monitoring-report) for a detailed explanation.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

Item2.Name: Poverty gap at $2.5 a day (PPP) (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The mean shortfall from the $2.5 a day poverty line (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall), expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

Item2.Name: Poverty gap at $4 a day (PPP) (%)
Item2.SourceNote: The mean shortfall from the $4 a day poverty line (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall), expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.

For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

Item2.Name: Poverty gap at $1.90 a day (2011 PPP) (%)
Item2.SourceNote: Poverty gap at $1.90 a day (2011 PPP) is the mean shortfall in income or consumption from the poverty line $1.90 a day (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall), expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence. As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions. Note: five countries -- Bangladesh, Cabo Verde, Cambodia, Jordan, and Lao PDR -- use the 2005 PPP conversion factors and corresponding $1.25 a day and $2 a day poverty lines. This is due to the large deviations in the rate of change in PPP factors relative to the rate of change in domestic consumer price indexes. See Box 1.1 in the Global Monitoring Report 2015/2016 (http://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/global-monitoring-report) for a detailed explanation.

Item2.Name: GINI index (World Bank estimate)
Item2.SourceNote: Gini index measures the extent to which the distribution of income (or, in some cases, consumption expenditure) among individuals or households within an economy deviates from a perfectly equal distribution. A Lorenz curve plots the cumulative percentages of total income received against the cumulative number of recipients, starting with the poorest individual or household. The Gini index measures the area between the Lorenz curve and a hypothetical line of absolute equality, expressed as a percentage of the maximum area under the line. Thus a Gini index of 0 represents perfect equality, while an index of 100 implies perfect inequality.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

Item2.Name: Poverty gap at national poverty lines (%)
Item2.SourceNote: Poverty gap at national poverty lines is the mean shortfall from the poverty lines (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall) as a percentage of the poverty lines. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are compiled from official government sources or are computed by World Bank staff using national (i.e. country–specific) poverty lines.

Item2.Name: Poverty headcount ratio at national poverty lines (% of population)
Item2.SourceNote: National poverty headcount ratio is the percentage of the population living below the national poverty lines. National estimates are based on population-weighted subgroup estimates from household surveys.
Item2.SourceOrg: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are compiled from official government sources or are computed by World Bank staff using national (i.e. country–specific) poverty lines.

Item2.Name: Child employment in agriculture, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
Item2.SourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.

Item2.Name: Employment in agriculture, female (% of female employment)
Item2.SourceNote: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. The agriculture sector consists of activities in agriculture, hunting, forestry and fishing, in accordance with division 1 (ISIC 2) or categories A-B (ISIC 3) or category A (ISIC 4).
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.SourceNote: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. Item2.Name: Share of women in wage employment in the nonagricultural sector (% of total nonagricultural employment)
Item2.SourceNote: Share of women in wage employment in the nonagricultural sector is the share of female workers in wage employment in the nonagricultural sector (industry and services), expressed as a percentage of total employment in the nonagricultural sector. Industry includes mining and quarrying (including oil production), manufacturing, construction, electricity, gas, and water, corresponding to divisions 2-5 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories C-F (ISIC revision 3). Services include wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services-corresponding to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories G-P (ISIC revision 3).

Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Wage and salaried workers, female (% of females employed)
Item2.SourceNote: Wage and salaried workers (employees) are those workers who hold the type of jobs defined as "paid employment jobs," where the incumbents hold explicit (written or oral) or implicit employment contracts that give them a basic remuneration that is not directly dependent upon the revenue of the unit for which they work.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Wage and salary workers, male (% of males employed)
Item2.SourceNote: Wage and salaried workers (employees) are those workers who hold the type of jobs defined as "paid employment jobs," where the incumbents hold explicit (written or oral) or implicit employment contracts that give them a basic remuneration that is not directly dependent upon the revenue of the unit for which they work.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Wage and salaried workers, total (% of total employed)
Item2.SourceNote: Wage and salaried workers (employees) are those workers who hold the type of jobs defined as "paid employment jobs," where the incumbents hold explicit (written or oral) or implicit employment contracts that give them a basic remuneration that is not directly dependent upon the revenue of the unit for which they work.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Children in employment, unpaid family workers (% of children in employment, ages 7-14)
Item2.SourceNote: Unpaid family workers are people who work without pay in a market-oriented establishment operated by a related person living in the same household.
Item2.SourceOrg: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

Item2.Name: Contributing family workers, female (% of females employed)
Item2.SourceNote: Contributing family workers are those workers who hold  ‘self-employment jobs’ as own-account workers in a market-oriented establishment operated by a related person living in the same household.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Contributing family workers, male (% of males employed)
Item2.SourceNote: Contributing family workers are those workers who hold "self-employment jobs" as own-account workers in a market-oriented establishment operated by a related person living in the same household.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Contributing family workers, total (% of total employed)
Item2.SourceNote: Contributing family workers are those workers who hold "self-employment jobs" as own-account workers in a market-oriented establishment operated by a related person living in the same household.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: GDP per person employed (constant 2011 PPP $)
Item2.SourceNote: GDP per person employed is gross domestic product (GDP) divided by total employment in the economy. Purchasing power parity (PPP) GDP is GDP converted to 2011 constant international dollars using PPP rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP that a U.S. dollar has in the United States.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: GDP per person employed (annual % growth)
Item2.SourceNote: GDP per person employed is gross domestic product (GDP) divided by total employment in the economy.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Employment in industry, female (% of female employment)
Item2.SourceNote: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. The industry sector consists of mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water), in accordance with divisions 2-5 (ISIC 2) or categories C-F (ISIC 3) or categories B-F (ISIC 4).
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Employment in industry, male (% of male employment)
Item2.SourceNote: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. The industry sector consists of mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water), in accordance with divisions 2-5 (ISIC 2) or categories C-F (ISIC 3) or categories B-F (ISIC 4).
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Employment in industry (% of total employment)
Item2.SourceNote: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. The industry sector consists of mining and quarrying, manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water), in accordance with divisions 2-5 (ISIC 2) or categories C-F (ISIC 3) or categories B-F (ISIC 4).
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Informal employment, female (% of total non-agricultural employment)
Item2.SourceNote: Employment in the informal economy as a percentage of total non-agricultural employment. It basically includes all jobs in unregistered and/or small-scale private unincorporated enterprises that produce goods or services meant for sale or barter. Self-employed street vendors, taxi drivers and home-base workers, regardless of size, are all considered enterprises. However, agricultural and related activities, households producing goods exclusively for their own use (e.g. subsistence farming, domestic housework, care work, and employment of paid domestic workers), and volunteer services rendered to the community are excluded.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Informal employment, male (% of total non-agricultural employment)
Item2.SourceNote: Employment in the informal economy as a percentage of total non-agricultural employment. It basically includes all jobs in unregistered and/or small-scale private unincorporated enterprises that produce goods or services meant for sale or barter. Self-employed street vendors, taxi drivers and home-base workers, regardless of size, are all considered enterprises. However, agricultural and related activities, households producing goods exclusively for their own use (e.g. subsistence farming, domestic housework, care work, and employment of paid domestic workers), and volunteer services rendered to the community are excluded.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Child employment in manufacturing, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
Item2.SourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Manufacturing corresponds to division 3 (ISIC revision 2) or category D (ISIC revision 3). Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
Item2.SourceOrg: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

Item2.SourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.

Item2.Name: Children in employment, self-employed (% of children in employment, ages 7-14)
Item2.SourceNote: Self-employed workers are people whose remuneration depends directly on the profits derived from the goods and services they produce, with or without other employees, and include employers, own-account workers, and members of producers cooperatives.

Item2.Name: Child employment in services, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
Item2.SourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade, hotels and restaurants, transport, financial intermediation, real estate, public administration, education, health and social work, other community services, and private household activity. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
Item2.SourceOrg: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
Item2.SourceOrg: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

Item2.Name: Employment in services, female (% of female employment)
Item2.SourceNote: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. The services sector consists of wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services, in accordance with divisions 6-9 (ISIC 2) or categories G-Q (ISIC 3) or categories G-U (ISIC 4).
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.SourceNote: Employment is defined as persons of working age who were engaged in any activity to produce goods or provide services for pay or profit, whether at work during the reference period or not at work due to temporary absence from a job, or to working-time arrangement. Item2.Name: Labor force (15-24 years), female
Item2.SourceNote: Total labor force comprises people ages 15 to 24 who meet the International Labour Organization definition of the economically active population: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. It includes both the employed and the unemployed. While national practices vary in the treatment of such groups as the armed forces and seasonal or part-time workers, in general the labor force includes the armed forces, the unemployed, and first-time job-seekers, but excludes homemakers and other unpaid caregivers and workers in the informal sector.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.SourceNote: Labor participation rate, female (% of female population ages 15-24)

Item2.Name: Labor force, total
Item2.SourceNote: Total labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization definition of the economically active population: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. It includes both the employed and the unemployed. While national practices vary in the treatment of such groups as the armed forces and seasonal or part-time workers, in general the labor force includes the armed forces, the unemployed, and first-time job-seekers, but excludes homemakers and other unpaid caregivers and workers in the informal sector.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, using World Bank population estimates.

Item2.Name: Labor force, male
Item2.SourceNote: Male labor force comprises all males who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, using World Bank population estimates.

Item2.Name: Labor force, male (% of total labor force)
Item2.SourceNote: Male labor force as a percentage of the total show the extent to which men are active in the labor force. Labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, using World Bank population estimates.

Item2.SourceNote: Ratio of female to male youth unemployment rate (% ages 15-24)

Item2.SourceNote: Youth unemployment refers to the share of the labor force ages 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment.
Item2.SourceOrg: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

Item2.Name: Unemployment, youth total (% of total labor force ages 15-24) (modeled ILO estimate)
Item2.SourceNote: Youth unemployment refers to the share of the labor force ages 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment.

Item2.SourceNote: Long-term unemployment refers to the number of people with continuous periods of unemployment extending for a year or longer, expressed as a percentage of the total unemployed.
